notes:
1. Definitions

  • A Shaft is a rotating machine element, usually circular in cross-section, which is used to transmit power from one part to another, or from a machine which produces power to a machine which absorbs power. It is subjected to torsion and bending moments.
  • An Axle is a non-rotating or stationary member that supports rotating components like wheels or pulleys. It is primarily subjected to bending moments and carries no torque.

2. Power, Torque, and Speed

The primary function of a shaft is to transmit power. The power transmitted by a shaft is related to the torque it carries and its rotational speed.

$$P = T \omega = \frac{2\pi n T}{60}$$
  • $P$ is Power in Watts (W).
  • $T$ is Torque in Newton-meters (N·m).
  • $\omega$ is the angular velocity in radians per second (rad/s).
  • $n$ is the rotational speed in revolutions per minute (rpm).

solvedExamples.question: A shaft is rotating at 1200 rpm and transmits a torque of 150 N·m. What is the power transmitted?
solvedExamples.explanation:
Use the power formula $P = \frac{2\pi n T}{60}$.
$P = \frac{2\pi (1200 \text{ rpm})(150 \text{ N·m})}{60} = 2\pi (20)(150) = 6000\pi \approx 18850$ W, which is 18.85 kW.

solvedExamples.question: What is the primary loading difference between a shaft and an axle?

options.text: Shafts are loaded in tension, axles in compression.
Shafts are subjected to torsion, while axles are not.
Axles are subjected to torsion, while shafts are not.
Shafts are only subjected to bending, axles to torsion.

solvedExamples.explanation: The defining characteristic of a shaft is that it rotates to transmit torque (torsional load). An axle is a stationary member that supports rotating parts and is mainly subjected to bending loads from that support.
